replies.body: We're aiming to buff a number of tanks in the jungle in patch 5.5 and/or patch 5.6 (5.3's the current live patch, design work on 5.4's just finished for context). To start with that'll involve looking at tanks that are struggling a bit (definitely Zac, potentially Nautilus, Nunu etc).

? Nunu is the only one who performs fine...
What about Rammus and Ammmu? Both were gutted on the very day the new jungle was originally introduced without further testing.

Not to mention that ever since, the jungle only became tougher and the tools on hand worsened (monster buffs, vs. several smite nerfs, several jungle item nerfs)

P.S: Being able to barely clear the jungle doesn't equal viability.

Rammus and Amumu will both be looked at to see what they need, though potentially as part of a second set (whether in the same patch cycle or a later one) depending on how long work on the first set takes.

What about Jungle Leona? I've been doing that a lot in TB lately, and it has some pretty nasty ganks. Will she be getting any jungle buffs for more high-tier viability in that role, or is that too much power?

Leona doesn't need to be able to jungle.  I'm more interested in making sure that champions like Amumu and Zac, who aren't viable laners, can be viable junglers: adding the option to jungle a champ that can lane is less important, and in her case, will probably make support Leonas either overpowered or unhappy.
Why should she be confined only to support?

Because that's where she's balanced. As a Leona main, I'm sympathetic to the desire to play her in other lanes (top lane is usually good for a laugh). Unfortunately, balancing the game around letting her play in places where she'd be scary good (like jungle) creates needs to nerf her and as such destroy her primary role. Look at what happened to champs like Alistar, Soraka, and Lulu in the past - in all cases the champs went through extended periods where they weren't viable as supports because they had to be nerfed out of other roles (Jungle Ali, Mid Lulu, Mid Soraka).

It's always fun to try new things with odd champs, and ideally champs could be used in more than one way. Unfortunately, champs that are powerful in multiple roles tend to be overpowered in general (hello Nidalee). By all means, keep trying Leona in new places (again, top, holy moses it can be fun) but i don't want her balanced towards that.
very well reasoned
You realize that she was originally intended as generic female full tank, and not merely a support tank right?
Considering her passive relies on her teammates, she was clearly designed to play a supportive role in a two person lane.
It was intended for team fights actually. Because those are what tanks are for. It's actually a great ganking tool as well.
Technically Zac can top lane just fine. (At least he used to)
Partially agreed. He has the sustain for it but his damage is so pitifully low he gets pushed back all the time by any other tank top lane.

**Thanks for your response!**
Another question:


Is there any chance to see an improvement to Trailblazer?

It was originally nerfed because the lower cooldown made it too powerful in terms of buff control. (Which was justified, BUT:)

Yet, the cooldown nerf came without compensation for those who relied on its sustain.

As i recall it ,one official statement early after the new jungle was introduced claimed that Trailblazer was partly the reason why jungle (-item) sustain was significantly worsened in the first place: Meaning you should gear up (by building Trailblazer) to improve it (Mreg/Hpreg).

The original Trailblazer already was lackluster in terms of accomplishing the job as a sustain tool, but nerfing it's cooldown TWICE (from 45s to 75s) definitely destroyed any chance to serve that purpose for sure.

So, just for some context here, the item sustain has been tuned around jungle goals and not the other way around. That is, taking camps is supposed to cost some of your resources and the items aren't supposed to be able to shortcut that too much.

We are definitely looking at the jungle items, with Skirmisher's Sabre and Poacher's Knife up for fairly significant changes, though maybe not on the same cadence that Meddler mentioned (those changes are targeted more at making sure the whole set ends up in a good place, not specifically at making particular junglers feel good). 

We're also looking at the enchantments - no details right now, but Juggernaut is on our hit list both in final item and build path, with the goal of making it actually work for jungle tanks. There are a few other things in progress right now, and we'll see where they land.

Tl;dr: Trailblazer itself is unlikely to receive buffs, but we hear you on jungle tanks and we are working on it. We want those champs to feel good to play.

Serious question, why even attempt to fix the jungler's when the itemization is  so messed up?  Right now there is nothing you can actually do to the tanks that will put them on par with anyone that can use Warrior's enchant UNLESS you make them stupidly overpowered, in which case they will never be played in the jungle and they will simply crush lanes (Maokai anyone?).

Normally I give Riot the benefit of the doubt but the new jungle enchantments are TERRIBLE, so I am going to post this giant wall of text hoping some of these issues are addressed in the changes.

Short version:  AP Champions deal approximate 30% less damage in the jungle compared to their AD counter parts, this discrepancy occurs entirely due to auto attacks.  Tanks are in an even worse spot.  That aside all enchantment build paths are complete shit compared to warrior enchant due to partial component cost.


This may be easiest to explain looking at how individual stats interact in the jungle and what getting more of this stat provides for a jungler.

* AD.  If you get more you kill things faster.  The faster you kill things the less time you spend fighting monsters, less in combat time means less damage taken PLUS fewer abilities used meaning less mana used.  Meaning by adding AD you are actually also sorta adding health and mana.  This is easily demonstrated by playing the same champion and buying a long sword (and no potions) and buying a ruby crystal.  Then going and clearing, at the end of the same number of camps the champion that bought the long sword will have the same or higher finishing health AND mana, PLUS they will still have the 10 damage the long sword provided them.  So in the end the champion that bought the ruby crystal is out damage, health, and mana.

* AP.  In large quantities AP is good and allows you to clear quickly, however it typically only applies to abilities resulting in weak auto attacks.  As an example at level 1 while an AD champion gets slightly more AS and about 20 extra AD from runes and masteries, the AP champion will get about 30 AP.  In lane this would be roughly even.  This isn't the case in the jungle since AP does not meaningfully improve auto attacks at early levels.  Meaning even if there is a 1.0 AP ratio compared to a .5 AD ratio on a first ability.  The AP champion will get 30 damage from AP then wait 5-10 seconds to use it again.  The AD champion on the other hand will get 10 damage from the ability PLUS 20 damage onto every single auto attack they make.  In 5-10 seconds you are looking at 4-8 auto attacks (80-160 damage), that the AD champions pick up just in the first spell rotation alone.  In an initial clear of 3 camps, AD champions will be about 750 damage ahead of their AP counter parts when they finish, or to put that in more contextual game terms roughly 10 auto attacks plus a round of abilities for the AP jungler.

* Health.  More health means you can take more damage.  In the jungle flat health is really actually pretty bad early it doesn't give you any damage so you end up taking more damage than what any health itemization or runes/masteries give you.  At least armor reduces the damage you take improving the efficiency of health pots, health on the other hand does not.  For this reason many tank junglers end up with damage oriented runes and often take some damage related masteries to allow them to make it through early clears.  The other problem with health is as jungle camps level up it still provides no damage, the time for a tank jungler to clear a camp remains high through the entire game.  While any type of damage jungler will see faster camp clears as they build items.

* AS, more autos, more damage, more damage, less combat time, less combat time less damage taken and fewer abilities used, less damage taken and fewer abilities used more health more mana.  It is a solid stat.


So you can already see some pretty clear issues with the stats that SHOULD have been addressed in development of the item, and I would say as completed items go Warrior, Magus, and Devourer are all approximately close to each other, although Magus does lag behind slightly (a different story we are talking about tanks), Juggernaut on the other hand is pretty terrible, as an item it is okay except it is needed in the jungle.  There is a reason why even J4 who is strong has almost exclusively swapped over to Warrior over Juggernaut, if he goes juggernaut he will rapidly begin to fall behind, and we are seeing the same issue the old jungle items had, that the early damage allowed you to tank up faster.

Build path:  I am glad to hear you are looking at build paths because right now Warrior's build path is 10x better than any other build path, because longswords are OP.

* Long sword vs ruby crystal buy:  Junglers back with 400g, AD jungler gets a longsword and a health potion.  As a result they get 10 damage and 150 health for their next journey into the jungle.  The tank gets 150 health.  Guess who does better?  Surprise the long sword wins, not only do you kill camps faster taking less damage and using less mana, you can get that health back, this allows you to apply pressure in lanes or at worse clear another camp that will more than pay for that health potion, all in the same amount of time.  The sad thing is it gets worse for other items.

* Long sword vs amp tome:  Junglers back with 435g, the AP jungler walks out with 20 AP.  The AD jungler has choices now! They can walk out with 10 AD and 2 pots (300 health) or 10 AD and a ward.  Plus it is still early in the game where auto attacks are a major portion of the damage in early jungle clears.  So not only does the AD jungler still clear faster, they either have more consumables than their counter parts or they have a ward to get vision advantage.

* Long sword vs dagger:  Junglers back with 450g.  AS jungler gets a dagger, the AD jungler has choices upon choices.  They can wait a second or two and get 3 potions, a green ward and a potion, or a pink ward.  Again all around massive advantages that in this case will easily translate into more benefits for the AD jungler compared to their counterpart.  

At the end of the day AD junglers have an advantage at level 1 because AD is simply the best stat in the game for clearing a jungle (well rivaled by AS at level 1), simply because auto attacks are such a major portion of the damage in the early jungle.  While building the enchantment AD junglers once again have an advantage simply due to the cost of the longsword being significantly cheaper than other enchantment components, even if it sets the jungler back 35-100g on a back that money is more than made up with the potions/wards that are bought.  Normally you trade off a strong early game for a weaker late game, AD junglers don't actually lose an advantages later in the game.

So what each jungle item needs:  AP item needs sustained damage (give the machete burn a 0.7 AP ratio).  Tanks need their stats to provide some form of improved clear, not only early in the game but it needs to scale later in the game.  Sapping barbs that were introduced was a good concept but lacked the scaling into late game that the damage builds had.  AS junglers are close enough to fine they are a pretty specialized group and with infinite scaling comes balance issues.

I also just want to say with the addition of PBE tracking jungle statistics.  This will show the discrepancy between the stats, but it will not show the discrepancy caused from the advantageous build path for warrior enchant. One thing I hope you collect data on (not show obviously) is when different jungle enchants are completed.  The cost of all ~~three~~ four (whoops) enchants are the same, but what is the average completion time for the various jungle enchants.


All around I also just want to say thank you for finally beginning to address the persistent issues that are in the jungle, this was not a problem caused by the jungle changes, these issues were prevalent even in the old jungle and it is largely itemization driven due to the challenge of balancing an item for multiple champions.

Just curious why attempt to fix the champions when the jungle items are woefully unbalanced right now?  Right now if you were to straight buff any tank junglers to the point where they are on par with Warrior enchant users, they will still not see jungle play, they will simply be played in lane.  Juggernaut is a terrible item for clearing the jungle, the build path to juggernaut is even worse, the end result is if you play a tanky champion in the jungle they just fall woefully behind.  Alternatively if you are going to buff the champions first then you would have to add individual improvements to their clear which just is a lot more work and coding that needs to be done.  Finally if you fix the champions and ever get around to fixing the jungle item then you have to go back through and nerf the champions you buffed.

All in all while I would love to see tank junglers back in action.  Improving individual junglers is not a quality solution as it ignores the core problem:  Tank stats don't clear the jungle well. This was the same issue with the last set of jungle items, why build the tank item when you can build the damage item clear faster and impact the map more resulting in you being tankier sooner AND having more damage.  Fix the items and a lot of the problems are fixed.

And a side note the build paths desperately need to be addressed.  Build paths are one of the primary reasons why even if you buff individual champions, unless you make them absurdly overpowered they will not be on an equal footing to warrior users.  The jungle enchants really need to function like Viktor's hexcore, because the difference in cost between a long sword and other initial components really punishes non-ad junglers.  A warrior user has at least 40 extra gold to play with compared to other junglers backing at the same time, they have close to 100g when compared to the AS junglers.  Early pots and wards are huge and the 35-100g you invest in them early almost always will pay off and more than offset the costs.

>where EVERY tank falls off.

I heavily disagree with this. Amumu and Sej are probably the two best examples of tanks with amazing late games. They both hyper scale into the late game, out scaling even the majority of bruisers in terms of not only CC and durability but also even damage in a lot of cases. As the game goes on these characters become more and more relevant thanks to their ability to peel anything not named Olaf off of their carries while still outputting high amounts of AOE damage and bringing a solid initiation threat.

There are also several tanks who scale well into late game by being great at one particular aspect and just outclassing the rest of the roster at that. Naut and Ali for example just become indestructible CC machines who are constant team fight threats because they will CC all of your carries and if you waste time killing them they most likely just win anyway. Cho'gath and Nunu both create huge zones in a team fight whilst having a spell that out-damages smite, giving them unparalleled objective control. (as long as we arn't counting Kalista, she's bat-shit insane)

Tanks have never had a problem late game. Generally speaking in a game type where everyone started out 6 items lv 18 you would chose a tank over the majority of bruisers. True late game tanks like Sej and Mumu can even give bruisers like Jax a run for his money in terms of overall effectiveness in a late game scenario. The problem that tanks have is that they have incredibly weak early games that you have to work around and at the moment champs who can shut them down early **are the meta**.
